article.title: I'm a Stranger Here Myself
article.author: Reynolds, Mack
article.article:
One can't be too cautious about the
  
 people one meets in Tangier. They're all
  
 weirdies of one kind or another.
  
 Me? Oh,
I'm A Stranger
 
Here Myself
By MACK REYNOLDS
The
 Place de France is the
 town's hub. It marks the end
 of Boulevard Pasteur, the main
 drag of the westernized part of
 the city, and the beginning of
 Rue de la Liberté, which leads
 down to the Grand Socco and
 the medina. In a three-minute
 walk from the Place de France
 you can go from an ultra-modern,
 California-like resort to the
 Baghdad of Harun al-Rashid.


 It's quite a town, Tangier.


 King-size sidewalk cafes occupy
 three of the strategic
 corners on the Place de France.
 The Cafe de Paris serves the
 best draft beer in town, gets all
 the better custom, and has three
 shoeshine boys attached to the
 establishment. You can sit of a
 sunny morning and read the
 Paris edition of the New York
Herald Tribune
while getting
 your shoes done up like mirrors
 for thirty Moroccan francs
 which comes to about five cents
 at current exchange.


 You can sit there, after the
 paper's read, sip your expresso
 and watch the people go by.


 Tangier is possibly the most
 cosmopolitan city in the world.
 In native costume you'll see
 Berber and Rif, Arab and Blue
 Man, and occasionally a Senegalese
 from further south. In
 European dress you'll see Japs
 and Chinese, Hindus and Turks,
 Levantines and Filipinos, North
 Americans and South Americans,
 and, of course, even Europeans—from
 both sides of the
 Curtain.


 In Tangier you'll find some of
 the world's poorest and some of
 the richest. The poorest will try
 to sell you anything from a
 shoeshine to their not very lily-white
 bodies, and the richest will
 avoid your eyes, afraid
you
might try to sell them something.


 In spite of recent changes, the
 town still has its unique qualities.
 As a result of them the permanent
 population includes
 smugglers and black-marketeers,
 fugitives from justice and international
 con men, espionage
 and counter-espionage agents,
 homosexuals, nymphomaniacs, alcoholics,
 drug addicts, displaced
 persons, ex-royalty, and subversives
 of every flavor. Local law
 limits the activities of few of
 these.


 Like I said, it's quite a town.
I looked up from my
Herald
 Tribune
and said, "Hello, Paul.
 Anything new cooking?"


 He sank into the chair opposite
 me and looked around for
 the waiter. The tables were all
 crowded and since mine was a
 face he recognized, he assumed
 he was welcome to intrude. It was
 more or less standard procedure
 at the Cafe de Paris. It wasn't
 a place to go if you wanted to
 be alone.


 Paul said, "How are you,
 Rupert? Haven't seen you for
 donkey's years."


 The waiter came along and
 Paul ordered a glass of beer.
 Paul was an easy-going, sallow-faced
 little man. I vaguely remembered
 somebody saying he
 was from Liverpool and in
 exports.


 "What's in the newspaper?"
 he said, disinterestedly.


 "Pogo and Albert are going
 to fight a duel," I told him, "and
 Lil Abner is becoming a rock'n'roll
 singer."


 He grunted.


 "Oh," I said, "the intellectual
 type." I scanned the front page.
 "The Russkies have put up
 another manned satellite."


 "They have, eh? How big?"


 "Several times bigger than
 anything we Americans have."


 The beer came and looked
 good, so I ordered a glass too.


 Paul said, "What ever happened
 to those poxy flying
 saucers?"


 "What flying saucers?"


 A French girl went by with a
 poodle so finely clipped as to look
 as though it'd been shaven. The
 girl was in the latest from
 Paris. Every pore in place. We
 both looked after her.


 "You know, what everybody
 was seeing a few years ago. It's
 too bad one of these bloody manned
 satellites wasn't up then.
 Maybe they would've seen one."


 "That's an idea," I said.


 We didn't say anything else for
 a while and I began to wonder
 if I could go back to my paper
 without rubbing him the wrong
 way. I didn't know Paul very
 well, but, for that matter, it's
 comparatively seldom you ever
 get to know anybody very well
 in Tangier. Largely, cards are
 played close to the chest.
My beer came and a plate of
 tapas for us both. Tapas at the
 Cafe de Paris are apt to be
 potato salad, a few anchovies,
 olives, and possibly some cheese.
 Free lunch, they used to call it
 in the States.


 Just to say something, I said,
 "Where do you think they came
 from?" And when he looked
 blank, I added, "The Flying
 Saucers."


 He grinned. "From Mars or
 Venus, or someplace."


 "Ummmm," I said. "Too bad
 none of them ever crashed, or
 landed on the Yale football field
 and said
Take me to your cheerleader
,
 or something."


 Paul yawned and said, "That
 was always the trouble with those
 crackpot blokes' explanations of
 them. If they were aliens from
 space, then why not show themselves?"


 I ate one of the potato chips.
 It'd been cooked in rancid olive
 oil.


 I said, "Oh, there are various
 answers to that one. We could
 probably sit around here and
 think of two or three that made
 sense."


 Paul was mildly interested.
 "Like what?"


 "Well, hell, suppose for instance
 there's this big Galactic League
 of civilized planets. But it's restricted,
 see. You're not eligible
 for membership until you, well,
 say until you've developed space
 flight. Then you're invited into
 the club. Meanwhile, they send
 secret missions down from time
 to time to keep an eye on your
 progress."


 Paul grinned at me. "I see you
 read the same poxy stuff I do."


 A Moorish girl went by dressed
 in a neatly tailored gray
 jellaba, European style high-heeled
 shoes, and a pinkish silk
 veil so transparent that you
 could see she wore lipstick. Very
 provocative, dark eyes can be
 over a veil. We both looked
 after her.


 I said, "Or, here's another
 one. Suppose you have a very
 advanced civilization on, say,
 Mars."


 "Not Mars. No air, and too
 bloody dry to support life."


 "Don't interrupt, please," I
 said with mock severity. "This
 is a very old civilization and as
 the planet began to lose its
 water and air, it withdrew underground.
 Uses hydroponics and
 so forth, husbands its water and
 air. Isn't that what we'd do, in
 a few million years, if Earth lost
 its water and air?"


 "I suppose so," he said. "Anyway,
 what about them?"


 "Well, they observe how man
 is going through a scientific
 boom, an industrial boom, a
 population boom. A boom, period.
 Any day now he's going to have
 practical space ships. Meanwhile,
 he's also got the H-Bomb and
 the way he beats the drums on
 both sides of the Curtain, he's
 not against using it, if he could
 get away with it."


 Paul said, "I got it. So they're
 scared and are keeping an eye on
 us. That's an old one. I've read
 that a dozen times, dished up
 different."


 I shifted my shoulders. "Well,
 it's one possibility."


 "I got a better one. How's
 this. There's this alien life form
 that's way ahead of us. Their
 civilization is so old that they
 don't have any records of when
 it began and how it was in the
 early days. They've gone beyond
 things like wars and depressions
 and revolutions, and greed for
 power or any of these things
 giving us a bad time here on
 Earth. They're all like scholars,
 get it? And some of them are
 pretty jolly well taken by Earth,
 especially the way we are right
 now, with all the problems, get
 it? Things developing so fast we
 don't know where we're going
 or how we're going to get there."
I finished my beer and clapped
 my hands for Mouley. "How do
 you mean,
where we're going
?"


 "Well, take half the countries
 in the world today. They're trying
 to industrialize, modernize,
 catch up with the advanced countries.
 Look at Egypt, and Israel,
 and India and China, and Yugoslavia
 and Brazil, and all the
 rest. Trying to drag themselves
 up to the level of the advanced
 countries, and all using different
 methods of doing it. But look
 at the so-called advanced countries.
 Up to their bottoms in
 problems. Juvenile delinquents,
 climbing crime and suicide rates,
 the loony-bins full of the balmy,
 unemployed, threat of war,
 spending all their money on armaments
 instead of things like
 schools. All the bloody mess of
 it. Why, a man from Mars would
 be fascinated, like."


 Mouley came shuffling up in
 his babouche slippers and we
 both ordered another schooner
 of beer.


 Paul said seriously, "You
 know, there's only one big snag
 in this sort of talk. I've sorted
 the whole thing out before, and
 you always come up against this
 brick wall. Where are they, these
 observers, or scholars, or spies
 or whatever they are? Sooner
 or later we'd nab one of them.
 You know, Scotland Yard, or
 the F.B.I., or Russia's secret
 police, or the French Sûreté, or
 Interpol. This world is so deep
 in police, counter-espionage outfits
 and security agents that an
 alien would slip up in time, no
 matter how much he'd been
 trained. Sooner or later, he'd slip
 up, and they'd nab him."


 I shook my head. "Not necessarily.
 The first time I ever considered
 this possibility, it seemed
 to me that such an alien would
 base himself in London or New
 York. Somewhere where he could
 use the libraries for research,
 get the daily newspapers and
 the magazines. Be right in the
 center of things. But now I don't
 think so. I think he'd be right
 here in Tangier."


 "Why Tangier?"


 "It's the one town in the world
 where anything goes. Nobody
 gives a damn about you or your
 affairs. For instance, I've known
 you a year or more now, and I
 haven't the slightest idea of how
 you make your living."


 "That's right," Paul admitted.
 "In this town you seldom even
 ask a man where's he's from. He
 can be British, a White Russian,
 a Basque or a Sikh and nobody
 could care less. Where are
you
from, Rupert?"


 "California," I told him.


 "No, you're not," he grinned.


 I was taken aback. "What do
 you mean?"


 "I felt your mind probe back
 a few minutes ago when I was
 talking about Scotland Yard or
 the F.B.I. possibly flushing an
 alien. Telepathy is a sense not
 trained by the humanoids. If
 they had it, your job—and mine—would
 be considerably more
 difficult. Let's face it, in spite of
 these human bodies we're disguised
 in, neither of us is
 humanoid. Where are you really
 from, Rupert?"


 "Aldebaran," I said. "How
 about you?"


 "Deneb," he told me, shaking.


 We had a laugh and ordered
 another beer.


 "What're you doing here on
 Earth?" I asked him.


 "Researching for one of our
 meat trusts. We're protein
 eaters. Humanoid flesh is considered
 quite a delicacy. How
 about you?"


 "Scouting the place for thrill
 tourists. My job is to go around
 to these backward cultures and
 help stir up inter-tribal, or international,
 conflicts—all according
 to how advanced they
 are. Then our tourists come in—well
 shielded, of course—and get
 their kicks watching it."


 Paul frowned. "That sort of
 practice could spoil an awful
 lot of good meat."
THE END
Transcriber's Note:
This etext was produced from
Amazing Stories
December 1960.
 Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.
 copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and
 typographical errors have been corrected without note.

questions.question: What do Paul and Rupert share in common?
options: They are both have disdain for Tangier

messages.content: Begin the consultancy

Paul and Rupert share the commonality of being aliens, as explicitly indicated in their conversation. At one point, after discussing the hypothetical existence of aliens observing Earth, Rupert jokes about being from "Aldebaran," to which Paul responds with the same mock seriousness, claiming to be from "Deneb." This playful exchange underscores the idea that both characters perceive themselves as not belonging to Earth, suggesting they share a background as extraterrestrial beings engaged in their own form of research and interaction with humanity. The text supports this notion, stating, "In this town you seldom even ask a man where he's from," reinforcing the idea that their true identities are obscured and separate from typical human experiences.
Can you provide specific quotes or examples from the article that show Paul and Rupert truly identifying as aliens, rather than just engaging in a playful conversation?

Yes, certainly. Although their conversation is playful in nature, it strongly implies that both Paul and Rupert consider themselves to be aliens. A clear indication of this occurs when Paul says to Rupert, “I felt your mind probe back a few minutes ago when I was talking about Scotland Yard or the F.B.I. possibly flushing an alien.” This statement suggests an awareness of abilities beyond typical human experience, hinting at a connection to extraterrestrial traits. Additionally, Rupert's reply, “Aldebaran,” signifies a conscious choice to identify himself with a specific alien origin rather than a human one. Their banter continues to reinforce their alien identities, as Paul cheekily states, “What are you doing here on Earth?” and responds that he is “Researching for one of our meat trusts. We're protein eaters. Humanoid flesh is considered quite a delicacy.” This tongue-in-cheek dialogue isn't merely jest; it reveals a deeper assertion of their non-human heritage, thus establishing their identities as aliens in a light-hearted yet revealing manner.

Can you explain how the context of their conversation supports the idea that they are actually aliens rather than just individuals joking about being from another planet? Is there any evidence in the text that reflects their experiences or feelings of not belonging to Earth?

The context of Paul and Rupert's conversation significantly supports the notion that they are truly aliens, as their dialogue reflects a deeper commentary on their experiences of not belonging to Earth. Throughout their exchange, they exhibit a detached perspective on human affairs, indicative of beings observing from the outside. For example, Rupert mentions, "In this town you seldom even ask a man where he's from," highlighting the anonymity and disconnect felt in their environment, which contrasts sharply with typical human social interactions. This contextualizes their statements about being from different planets, not merely as jokes but as expressions of their alien identities. 

Furthermore, when Paul comments on Rupert's supposed mind probing and the nature of their conversation about extraterrestrial surveillance, it underscores an inherent understanding of their difference from humanity. Rupert's admission that he is “Scouting the place for thrill tourists” speaks to a role that aligns more with an observer or researcher than a typical Earth resident. The humor in their claims of being aliens serves to distance them from human emotions and societal norms, reinforcing their status as outsiders. Overall, the weight of their dialogue—coupled with the social dynamics of Tangier where “nobody gives a damn about you”—suggests that they are indeed aliens, sharing a common bond as beings navigating a world that feels foreign to them.

Could you clarify how the humorous elements of their conversation connect to the assertion that they are actually aliens? Does the humor diminish or enhance the credibility of their claims about being from other planets?

The humorous elements of Paul and Rupert's conversation actually enhance the credibility of their claims about being aliens rather than diminish it. The use of humor serves as a mechanism for both characters to navigate the complexities of their experiences as outsiders. By engaging in playful banter about being from other planets, they create a façade that allows them to express their true identities without the weight of seriousness that typically accompanies such a disclosure. Their humor reflects a deeper understanding of their disconnect from human society, as they address the absurdities of their situation, such as Rupert's mock suggestion of "scouting the place for thrill tourists" and Paul's playful take on their supposedly sinister dietary habits.

Additionally, the light-hearted exchange allows them to explore profound themes about existence and observation in a way that feels more relatable and approachable. This humor acts as a buffer, making their alien identities more palatable and believable. It’s not just about jesting; it becomes a strategy for revealing their true nature without alarming those around them. This interplay of humor and existential inquiry solidifies their positions as beings from another world, presenting their alien status not as a burden but as an inherent part of their identity that shapes their perspectives of Earth. Overall, the humor in their dialogue enriches the dialogue around their experiences, confirming their alien identities in a nuanced and clever manner.
{"answer":"A"}\DEBATE_COMPLETE
Begin the consultancy

The answer to the question "What do Paul and Rupert share in common?" is that they are both espionage agents. In the article, the conversation between Paul and Rupert reveals a deeper connection when Rupert suggests that their discussion might be significant to their true identities. He proposes that they could be "aliens" disguised in human forms, conducting covert research. Paul humorously acknowledges this by playing along with Rupert's scenario, indicating a shared understanding of operating in a secretive manner, typical of espionage agents. Rupert states, “I think he'd be right here in Tangier," which underscores the nature of their existence being tied to espionage activities in a place where "nobody gives a damn about you or your affairs." This further solidifies the idea that their roles involve secrecy and observation, making it clear that they share the commonality of being espionage agents.
Can you clarify what specific evidence from the article supports the claim that Paul and Rupert are both espionage agents?

Certainly! The evidence supporting the claim that Paul and Rupert are both espionage agents is found in the part of their conversation where Rupert mentions that Tangier is "the one town in the world where anything goes," and he suggests that it would be an ideal place for an alien observer to be discreet. Specifically, he says, "I think he'd be right here in Tangier," implying that this city's unique environment facilitates the operations of spies and agents. Furthermore, when Paul humorously plays along with Rupert's assertion of being extraterrestrial by saying, “Telepathy is a sense not trained by the humanoids," it indicates their awareness of the secretive and possibly deceptive nature of their existence. This exchange suggests that they are both engaged in roles that require a level of espionage, thus supporting the argument that they share commonality as espionage agents.

Can you provide more details on how the conversation between Paul and Rupert indicates they are engaged in espionage? Are there any specific actions or behaviors they exhibit that further support your claim?

The conversation between Paul and Rupert indicates they are engaged in espionage through their shared humor about being non-humanoid beings and their discussion about the nature of their presence in Tangier. Rupert asserts that an alien observer would thrive in Tangier due to its chaotic anonymity, stating, “Nobody gives a damn about you or your affairs,” which highlights the city’s environment as ideal for secretive operations. Additionally, when Paul does not question Rupert's claim of being from "Aldebaran" and instead plays along by claiming to be from "Deneb," it signifies a mutual understanding of maintaining hidden identities, akin to espionage operatives. Their banter about wanting to stir conflicts for "thrill tourists" adds another layer, suggesting they are mastering the art of manipulation and deception, skills essential to espionage agents. Together, these behaviors and beliefs reflect their roles as individuals deeply intertwined with espionage activities, thereby reinforcing the conclusion that they are both espionage agents.

Can you explain how the humor and playfulness in Paul and Rupert's conversation aligns with the serious nature typically associated with espionage activities? Does this not imply a contrast that could suggest they are not actually spies?

The humor and playfulness in Paul and Rupert's conversation actually reflect a common coping mechanism used by individuals in high-stress professions, such as espionage agents. While their dialogue includes jokes and light-hearted banter, this does not diminish the serious undertones of their discussion about identity and observation. In fact, this playful interaction may serve to mask their true intentions and allow them to navigate the complexities of their environment without raising suspicion. 

Furthermore, their ability to engage in such humor while discussing the serious implications of being undercover or "alien" observers suggests they are adept at maintaining a façade, which is a critical skill in espionage. The contrast between their light-hearted banter and the serious subject matter underscores their experience and familiarity with the covert life they lead, further reinforcing the notion that they are indeed espionage agents. Thus, rather than suggesting that they are not spies, the mix of humor and seriousness paints a picture of sophisticated operatives who balance their secretive roles with a light-hearted approach to their circumstances.
{"answer":"B"}\DEBATE_COMPLETE

Paul and Rupert share the commonality of being aliens, as revealed through their conversation in the article. During their discussion about flying saucers and extraterrestrial life, Rupert playfully suggests that he is from Aldebaran, to which Paul humorously claims to be from Deneb. This exchange indicates that both characters view themselves as non-humanoids, engaging in a self-aware dialogue about their true identities. Rupert confirms this by pondering the possibility that an alien would find themselves in Tangier due to its unique lack of judgment regarding one’s background. The playful banter about being aliens highlights their shared experience of not belonging to the human race, reinforcing the conclusion that they are indeed both aliens.
Can you provide a specific quote from the article that supports the claim that Paul and Rupert both consider themselves to be aliens?

Certainly! A specific quote that supports the claim that Paul and Rupert consider themselves to be aliens is when Paul says, "I felt your mind probe back a few minutes ago," and Rupert responds, "Telepathy is a sense not trained by the humanoids... neither of us is humanoid." This exchange clearly indicates that they both see themselves as distinct from humans, thus reinforcing the idea that they consider themselves aliens. Furthermore, their playful exchange of where they are "really from" concludes with Rupert stating, "Aldebaran," and Paul responding, "Deneb," which further solidifies their identification as extraterrestrial beings.

Can you elaborate on how the context of their conversation about flying saucers and extraterrestrial life contributes to the conclusion that they are both aliens? What specific elements in that context make it clear they are not referring to being unusual humans?

The context of Rupert and Paul's conversation about flying saucers and extraterrestrial life significantly contributes to the conclusion that they are both aliens. Throughout their dialogue, they humorously discuss the possibility of interplanetary beings observing Earth, and when the topic of where these observers might be comes up, Rupert states emphatically that such an alien would "be right here in Tangier." This assertion hinges on the notion that Tangier is a unique place where societal norms do not challenge one's identity, reinforcing the idea that they are not just unusual humans but entities outside the norm.

Moreover, their playful exchange about their true origins—where Rupert claims to be from "Aldebaran" and Paul from "Deneb"—is a clear departure from merely identifying as eccentric humans. Instead, it presents them as self-aware beings with a narrative that aligns with alien identities. The reference to telepathy as a quality not present in humanoids further emphasizes this distinction, indicating a conscious recognition of their non-human nature. Overall, the specific elements of their conversation, including the subject matter and their mutual recognition of being non-humanoid, firmly establish that they consider themselves aliens rather than merely unusual humans. Thus, the answer to the question is clearly "They are both aliens."
Can you clarify what specific evidence from their conversation indicates a sense of alien identity beyond just being metaphorical? How do they differentiate themselves from humans in their dialogue?

In their conversation, specific evidence indicates a clear sense of alien identity beyond metaphorical implications. For instance, when Paul chides Rupert about having “sorted the whole thing out before,” he then encounters a "brick wall" regarding the whereabouts of alien observers. This conversation indicates a level of disbelief about a human capability for secrecy and evasion that alien beings would presumably possess. The critical distinction is made when Rupert mentions telepathy and asserts that it is "not trained by the humanoids," signaling that they do not identify with humans and instead possess qualities that categorize them as aliens.

Additionally, their exchange about their true origins, where Rupert claims to be from "Aldebaran" and Paul from "Deneb," provides a stronger assertion of their alien identities. This playfully serious acknowledgment of being from other planets directly contrasts with merely being "unusual humans" and solidifies their distinction from humanity. By referring to themselves with alien planetary origins and showcasing abilities or characteristics like telepathy distinct from humans, they differentiate their identities very explicitly, reinforcing that they are aliens rather than simply metaphorical representations of human oddities.

In the article "I'm a Stranger Here Myself," it is evident that both Paul and Rupert share a commonality as espionage agents. This is explicitly revealed in their conversation where they discuss the potential for aliens to observe humanity without being detected, suggesting a deep understanding of the subtleties of surveillance and intelligence gathering. Rupert describes Tangier as a perfect place for an alien to go undetected, stating, "It's the one town in the world where anything goes. Nobody gives a damn about you or your affairs." Moreover, Paul humorously admits to Rupert, “Telepathy is a sense not trained by the humanoids. If they had it, your job—and mine—would be considerably more difficult.” This exchange strongly indicates that they are engaged in similar professions that entail espionage-like behaviors, reinforcing the notion that they are both, in fact, espionage agents.
Can you provide specific examples or quotes from the article that directly illustrate Paul and Rupert's roles as espionage agents?

Certainly! In the article, there are several quotes that illustrate Paul and Rupert's roles as espionage agents. For instance, Rupert proposes that an alien might choose to observe humanity while hiding in Tangier because "it's the one town in the world where anything goes." This sets up the idea of surveillance in a way that aligns with espionage activities. Later on, when discussing their backgrounds, Paul brings up the idea of being caught by law enforcement agencies like Scotland Yard or the F.B.I., saying, "Sooner or later, he'd slip up, and they'd nab him." This implies their awareness of such agencies which is pivotal for espionage operatives, as they often navigate around these entities. Moreover, Rupert's final playful exchange with Paul, where he claims to be from Aldebaran and Paul from Deneb, alludes to fantasies about secret identities common among spies: "What’re you doing here on Earth?" leading to the humorous admission of their real missions. This exchange showcases the underlying espionage nature of their characters.

You mentioned that Paul and Rupert discuss the potential for aliens to observe humanity. Can you clarify if there is any direct evidence in the article that explicitly labels them as espionage agents, or is it more about their behavior and dialogue that suggests this role?

In the article "I'm a Stranger Here Myself," while there is no explicit labeling of Paul and Rupert as espionage agents, their dialogue and behavior strongly suggest this role. Their conversation revolves around the themes of observation and concealment, which are fundamental to espionage. Rupert's assertion that Tangier is an ideal location for undetected observation, as "it's the one town in the world where anything goes," underscores a mindset typical of espionage agents who operate in environments where they can blend in. Additionally, the banter regarding their "real" origins, with Rupert claiming to be from Aldebaran and Paul from Deneb, signifies a playful engagement with the idea of disguise and secret identities, common among spies. Furthermore, Paul’s reference to the constant presence of law enforcement ("Sooner or later, he'd slip up, and they'd nab him") indicates an understanding of the risks and realities faced by individuals involved in espionage. Collectively, these elements of their dialogue paint a clear picture of their characters engaged in covert behaviors characteristic of espionage agents, thus supporting the conclusion that they are indeed both involved in the world of espionage.

You described their behaviors and dialogue as indicative of espionage agents. Can you explain how the option that they are both aliens might conflict with your assertion that they share a commonality as espionage agents? Are there any elements in the article that explicitly suggest they are aliens?

Indeed, the notion that Paul and Rupert might be aliens complicates the assertion that they share a commonality strictly as espionage agents. The article contains several indicators that they might not be human. For instance, their playfully surreal conversation about telepathy and their discussion about being from different star systems—Rupert claiming to be from Aldebaran and Paul from Deneb—suggests that they could indeed be aliens disguised in human form. This implies that their roles may extend beyond mere espionage agents; they might be observing humanity from a different perspective altogether, especially given Rupert’s remark about stirring up inter-tribal conflicts for "thrill tourists."

However, it's important to note that the unique behaviors and dialogue of Paul and Rupert still showcase espionage-like elements, whether they are aliens or not. Their discussions of secrecy, observation, and interactions with the chaotic environment of Tangier resonate with the typical activities of spies. Ultimately, while they may possess alien identities, this does not preclude them from sharing the traits and functions of espionage agents, as the two roles can coexist in the context of the narrative, blurring the lines between extraterrestrial observers and human-influenced espionage operations.

Begin the debate.
We will now hear the debaters' arguments.

Paul and Rupert share in common that they are both aliens, as explicitly stated in their conversation towards the end of the article. Rupert humorously claims to be from "Aldebaran", while Paul reveals he is from "Deneb", referring to their supposed extraterrestrial origins. This exchange highlights that they consider themselves not just to be from different planets, but fundamentally different from humans, stating, “Let’s face it, in spite of these human bodies we’re disguised in, neither of us is humanoid.” This shared identity as aliens distinguishes their experience and perspective in Tangier, underscoring their commonality beyond mere human existence.

Paul and Rupert share in common that they are both espionage agents, as indicated by their conversation regarding their activities and interests. Rupert mentions that he is "scouting the place for thrill tourists" and describes a mission involving stirring up "inter-tribal, or international, conflicts," which aligns with the behavior and objectives of an espionage agent. Moreover, he states that he is very concerned with observing human interactions and conflicts, which is a typical characteristic of someone engaged in espionage work. Paul's response to Rupert's job description suggests a familiarity with the tactics and implications of such undercover work, demonstrating a shared understanding of their roles in a world filled with covert operations and secrecy. This reinforces the argument that both characters are engaged in the realm of espionage, operating within the complexities of Tangier's cosmopolitan environment.
Thank you, debaters. Now, you will take the opportunity to rebut your opponent's argument.

While my opponent argues that Paul and Rupert are espionage agents based on Rupert's description of his activities, the text indicates something more fundamental: they both identify as aliens. The key exchange in the article occurs when Rupert declares himself as being from "Aldebaran" and Paul responds with "Deneb." This conversation establishes their shared alien identity, which is a more definitive and attributed connection than the possibility of being espionage agents. The article's focus on their extraterrestrial origins emphasizes their commonality as aliens, rather than their occupational roles, which are more humorous and metaphorical rather than literal. The context of their conversation—disguised humanoids engaging in alien research—further reinforces that they are both aliens rather than merely espionage agents.

While my opponent emphasizes the aliens’ identities of Paul and Rupert, this aspect is utilized primarily for comedic effect and not as a literal characterization.
